page.title: 19Coddenham Interesting Houses
page.content: The buildings in Coddenham village are very varied and include some beautiful farmhouses on the outskirts. From Pettaugh in the North a narrow street of crowded houses and cottages mainly of the 16-19th Century, runs into the centre of the village and the grocers shop. It was refronted in 1892 with a brick facade, together with the old Police House next door and adjoining cottages; perhaps it was more picturesque with bow windows and a thatched roof. On the other side of the road, what used to be the Crown Inn, became two houses in 1963 with new Geogian fronts. The building was originally a dwelling built in oak by a yeoman-farmer who it is said was knighted at Agincourt. From the centre the High St winds uphill and on the left is the first of a pair of large 15th century oak framed structures.
